comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: It certainly is two people face to face as the nuns had to have short hair under those yokes.  It actually looked a lot better from the front though they certainly looked very unweildly at the best of times.  My first car was similar to the Ford Cortina Mark 1 parked on the far side of Parnell Street and that was registered in 1964 BZH was the reg. though it was getting old when I bought it in the early 1970's.

comment._content: An intriguing view of the nun and her shadow ...waiting at the bus stop :) Even in 1964 such a headdress was very old-fashioned here. -- Seen on your photo stream. ( ?² )

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/31176851@N02] Very old-fashioned but very distinctive, and seems to have been a reason why people have such strong memories of this order...

comment.author: 23085117@N00
comment._content: I love cornettes! They were more normal wear at the time that the Daughters of Charity were founded. Like a lot of organizations that develop a uniform, the Daughters of Charity and other orders ended up preserving what was a contemporary form of dress long past its heyday. Similar thing happened with academic dress at university graduations. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cornette
